Louisville's "Hardest Working Man in Show Business"

Louisville front man has been entertaining visitors to his nightclub for 20 years

Alton Strupp, Louisville

"The crowds just feel you with energy"

 

At 62, Green still commands the stage with the energy of a man in his 20s

Share This Story
11
12
Share
Email
Comment

Growing up in the Newburg neighborhood of Louisville, Jerry Green can still remember the first time he strummed a guitar. He'd move his hand swiftly across the worn strands, doing his best impression of Elvis Presley's "You ain't Nothin' but a Hound Dog." It didn't matter that Elvis was white. It didn't matter that the guitar was a broom. All that mattered was the music.

In many ways, the humility and dedication behind those early ideals still defines the Louisville music celebrity today.

Videographer Alton Strupp profiles Jerry Green, The Hardest Working Man in Show Business

Green was born on July 6, 1952, the seventh of 10 siblings, it was a lively household at 3525 Marvin Avenue. If you were to drive by it today, you'd find a factory now sits where the Green home used to be. Times were tough, yet, like most families with little means, great joy was found in the most unlikely of places.

The family's first guitar would come from a landfill during a trip looking for scrap metal and cardboard, with his father and brothers, to sell to help put groceries on the table. In his autobiogaphy, "A View from the Stage," Green remembered that "my eyes lit up so big you would have thought we had found a million dollars."

A musical talent who would grow to tour the world and enjoy a career of decades was first discovered by process of deduction. "The five boys would be in one room and the girls would be in the next room," Earlene Green Thompson, Green's older sister, remembers. "When my mother and father would go to bed we would gather in one room and harmonize." Soon the siblings had determined, "Jerry was the only one that could sing."

By his late teens, Green was the front man in the Louisville group The Sonic Sounds. The group would expand to form an eight-piece touring group in The Unhooked Generation Show Band,. Opening for names like Earth, Wind and Fire, Three Dog Night, the Blue Notes, and Harold Melvin presented Jerry with his first chance at stardom.

"It was a roller coaster of emotions," Green said, after initial contact during a rehearsal in 1971 led to a signing offer by a Chicago record company. The groups' feelings were what you'd expect from any youth in a similar situation — pure thrills. But, when drugs were openly used at a signing party, Green made the decision to step away from the deal. The experience would shape Green's view of what life in mainstream music was all about and set him on a new path. He cried for hours.

Louisville entertainer Jerry Green combs his hair in the bathroom of his home south of Louisville. The preparation of his appearance on show nights is something he decided to make a signature with early on in his career. "I like to be clean cut. That's what I want to portray. Someone that is classy and dressy," Green said. Dec. 5, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Green brings a few changes of outfits with him each night to his shows. Each is ironed and placed in to a garment bag with not a detail missed. From the cuff links to the rings on his fingers, it's clear each piece was given careful consideration. Dec. 5, 2014  (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

Green pulls on the first jacket he will be wearing during his show Friday evening at his night club Jerry Green and Friends. " I always loved to play dress up," Green said with a laugh. "I have a purple jacket that I wear each night when I perform Prince's "Purple Rain."" Dec. 5, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Patrons and members of the Jerry Green and Friends band prepare to exit the lounge at a rainy three a.m. following their Friday night show. Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

A view of the flourescent Jerry Green and Friends sign sits behind the performer's microphone on an empty stage early Friday evening. Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Bill May, 66, has been coming to see Jerry Green play for over a decade, coming at least three to four nights-a-week. "I first met Jerry back at the Best Western when the club was off of Brownsboro Road," May said. "I've been coming ever since." Like many of the loyal patrons, it's the quality of the music that has always kept May coming back. "Jerry's one of he best performers here in Louisville," May said. "Once you've been here, you pass it a long to a friend. You have to go to Jerry's club for a good time." Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
When musician and music fan Mike Bell moved to Louisville from Washington, D.C. he set out to find a good place in town for his time off. After some asking around, he found himself inside Jerry Green's night club. "Jerry Green is one of the best musicians I've ever met," Bell said. "It was classy." The diversity of the people in the night club stood out to Bell and Green's meticulous approach to the music. "He reminds me of James Brown. If the band made a mistake, you'll see him turn around." After all of the years coming to the club, Bell is one of the regulars that call Jerry a friend. "He's a genuine person. A man of integrity," Bell said. "If he says he's going to do something, he's going to do it 100 percent." Dec. 6, 2014  (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
"I proposed to her right here at Jerry Green's," Dominick Barksdale, left, said in regard to his wife Tiffany Barksdale. Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Louisville entertainer Jerry Green is announced each week at his club beneath the Breckinridge Hotel as the "Hardest working man in show business." Any one that has seen him perform live may find that claim hard to debate. At 62, Green still leaves the stage each night Friday and Saturday night completely drenched in sweat. With a music career that began in his teenage years, Green still treats it's show like it could be his last. "I try to do every song like it's the first song," Green said. "I want my best to shine at all times." Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Freddy George plays the piano early Friday evening in Jerry Green and Friends nightclub. Dec. 5, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
A portrait of Robert Davis hangs in loving memory on the wall above the table that was his nightly spot inside Jerry Green and Friends night club. Davis was a regular from the beginning and as a result had his very one table permanently reserved. "We always called him 'our Bob'," Green said with a laugh. "He will be missed," Green wrote in his book "A View from the Stage." Dec. 5, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

Green wipes sweat from his brow as the night begins to pick up speed with Tina Metzler, from left, Pam Lambert, and Cindy Vaughn taking to the floor on a relatively slow Friday night. "It doesn't matter matter if you're black, white, pink, orange or what," Green said. "You come through those doors, you can check your color at the door, because we're going to have a good time." Dec. 5, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

The floor starts to fill up on a Friday night at Jerry Green and Friends. Saturday nights are typically the busiest nights of the week. "I read the crowd all of the time," Green said. "That's the longevity to me. Being able to see what's in this room and play to it." Green and his band will perform songs ranging from R&B to country. Louie Armstrong to Phantom of the Opera. Buy Photo Fullscreen
The red stage lights shine down on Jerry Green during his Friday night performance at the Jerry Green and Friends night club. The local legend began strumming on a broom when he was six years old growing up in the Newburg neighborhood in Louisville, Ky. One of ten siblings, it was decided early on that Jerry was the best singer of the lot. He would go on to be in bands with acts that took him on tours around the USA and the world. "At a young age I just loved music," Green said. "I'd listen to my father play and I just wanted to play that guitar." Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Donna Toogood is spun by her dance partner Friday evening at Jerry Green and Friends nightclub. Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Jerry Green hits a high chord as he belts in to his microphone during a Friday night performance at the Jerry Green and Friends night club under the Breckinridge Hotel. "I want my legacy to be known as a place that you could just come and have a good time," Green said. Green, 62, has had a music career that spans over nearly five decades and in 2014 he celebrated 20 years running his signature night club. "It's woven in to the fabric of my soul," Green said. Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Green holds his microphone in to the air after performing Prince's "Purple Rain" during a Friday night show. While his performance touches on a variety of singers, Green's range is impressive. "I want it to be as perfect as I can get it," Green said. "Sometimes I just look out at the audience and smile. All of these people come together and enjoy themselves." Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Jerry Green wipes the sweat from his forehead in the back hallway, just off of the stage, following the night a Friday night performance. The full-set lasted nearly three hours and included multiple outfit changes. "You are only as good as your last show," Green said. "You can do a thousand good shows, bt you do one bad one... that's the one people will judge you on." Dec. 6, 2014 (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

    The path led back to the River City, where Green's humble music roots began. For 20 years running, Green has ran his own nightclub, Jerry Green and Friends, on his own terms. At his present location under the Breckinridge Hotel, Green stops in to visit with loyal patrons almost every night. Dance lessons and performances by pianist Freddy George fill up most of the weekly schedule, but Thursday through Saturday, the weekly headliner takes to the stage.

    "When I first hit the stage I may know the first song, but I won't know the rest until I look at the crowd," Green said. "I read the crowd all of the time. That's the longevity to me. Being able to see what's in this room and play to it."

    Patrons from all story lines fill up the dance floor on Fridays and Saturdays — from regulars to newcomers, singles and the many lovers that felt their first spark right on the Jerry Green's dance floor.

    "I proposed to her right here at Jerry Green's," Dominick Barksdale, left, said in regard to his wife Tiffany Barksdale. Dec. 6, 2014
    (Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)

    "I proposed to her right here a Jerry Green's. The same place I met her," regular Dominick Barksdale, 38, said of his wife Tiffany Barksdale, 30. The two met during a step dance lesson and quickly hit it off. "We've met a lot of other couples that met here at Jerry Green's — every time we come here it's like we get to reminisce on how we met and how we fell in love."

    The intricate wood bar, chosen by Green himself, in many ways recalls memories of television's "Cheers" as you make your way around the stools. Bill May, 66, has been arriving early to secure his seat at Jerry's club since it was being run at the Brownsboro Road location. "Once you've been here once, you pass it to a friend," May said. "Even people that come down from the hotel, they go home and say, 'you have to go to Jerry's club for a good time.'"

    With music ranging from R&B to country, from Louie Armstrong to the Phantom of the Opera, Green seems to know no bounds as he plays to his crowds' desires. "You are only as good as your last show," Green said. "You can do a thousand good shows, but you do one bad one, that's what people will judge you on — I want my best to shine at all times."

      At 62, Green still commands the stage with the energy of a man in his 20s. Moving through the crowd hammering The Commodores' "Brick House," wiping the sweat from his brow with his handkerchief, it's no surprise where the "Hardest Working Man in Show Business," came from.

      "I'm going to sing until I can't sing anymore," Green said. "The crowds just feel you with energy. You just want to put out your very best and hope it comes back to you and most of the time, it does."

      COURIER-JOURNAL

      On Assignment: For photographer Alton Strupp, the job a blast, and no TNT to worry about
